_header: Each day me cometh tidings three
_description: Three Sorrowful Things — six lines in couplets

OxfJesus29.First Lines:
Yche day me cumeþ tydinges þreofor wel swiþe sore
                    beoþ heo…
OxfJesus29.Last Lines:
…Þe þridde is my meste kareÞat ich not hwider
                    ich scal fare
OxfJesus29.Editions:
Morris,  Richard,
                        ed.  
             An Old English Miscellany: A Bestiary, Kentish Sermons, Proverbs of
                Alfred and Religious Poems of the Thirteenth Century.
EETS
         o.s. 49 (1872); repr. 1988: 101.
Brown,  Carleton Fairchild,
                        ed.  
             English Lyrics of the XIIIth Century.
         Oxford: Clarendon, 1932: 18.
Silverstein,  Theodore,
                        ed.  
             Medieval English Lyrics.
         York Medieval Texts. London: Edw. Arnold, 1971: 20-1.

CamEmm27.First Lines:
Boe ware hoe ih boeAday me comeþ sorewen
                    þre…
CamEmm27.Last Lines:
…þat þridde is mi meste careNot ih þanne wider
                    ih schal fare
CamEmm27.Note:
Trans. ‘Sunt tria ve qui mescificant me nocte die
                    quoque…’, written to right.
CamEmm27.Editions:
Brown,  Carleton Fairchild,
                        ed.  
             English Lyrics of the XIIIth Century.
         Oxford: Clarendon, 1932: 19.

CamPem258.First Lines:
Heuerei deg me comez tiþings þre wel sori ben
                    wee…
CamPem258.Last Lines:
…þe þridde is mi moste kareþat I ne
                    wiȝtwider I sall fare
CamPem258.Editions:
Heffernan,  Thomas J. 
             “Unpublished Middle English Verses on ‘The Three Sorrowful
                Things.’” 
             Neuphilologische Mitteilungen
         83 (1982): 31-3: 33.
